channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Federal Experts Talk Bird Flu ‘What Ifs’ in WebMD Live Event
item.description: WebMD brought together experts from four federal agencies to talk prevention, monitoring, and what the “what ifs” of bird flu might look like.

item.title: My Word for 2024: Strong
item.description: Before I begin, know that I fully recognize that it’s May. I selected my word of the year way back in December of 2023. After letting it marinade for a few days, I spent an hour looking for the perfect bracelet on Etsy that would display its letters each and every day. I also knew... Read More

item.title: The Genius Tip Brooke Shields Swears By To "Rescue" Crepey Skin
item.description: Underrated and oh-so-simple.

item.title: Mayo Clinic Minute: No ‘lesser evil’ when it comes to tobacco use
item.description: Editors note: May 31 is World No Tobacco Day From the traditional cigarette to the modern electronic cigarette, from the communal hookah to the discreet pinch of smokeless tobacco, each has proven to be detrimental to a person's health. In this Mayo Clinic Minute, Dr. Jon Ebbert, medical director of the Mayo Clinic Nicotine Dependence Center, discusses […] The post Mayo Clinic Minute: No ‘lesser evil’ when it comes to tobacco use appeared first on Mayo Clinic News Network .

item.title: What’s Next in Health Care for Older Adults: Questions and Answers With John Whyte, MD
item.description: As WebMD’s chief medical officer, John Whyte, MD, is in a unique position to see both the current state of medical care for America’s older adults and the way things are trending for the future. We asked him to share his insight on a few topics, along with a bit of advice.

item.title: The Sound of Freedom
item.description: For a million years (more like 15,) I’ve been listening to a radio show: The Taylor Strecker Show. It’s a daily show that originated on SiriusXM and through a series of events became an independently broadcasted show on Patreon. There’s something interesting that happens when you listen to a daily show. You get to know... Read More

item.title: 2024 hurricane preparedness: Be ready for storm season
item.description: Each hurricane season, it is critical to take proactive steps to protect yourself, your family and your property. Hurricanes and other severe storm events can be devastating, but with proper preparation, you can minimize risks and stay safe. This year, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) National Weather Service forecasters predict an 85% chance […] The post 2024 hurricane preparedness: Be ready for storm season appeared first on Mayo Clinic News Network .

item.title: Get the Care You Need in a COVID-19 World
item.description: What to expect at the doctor’s office, hospitals, and long-term care facilities, the future of telemedicine, and how to get the best care during COVID-19.

item.title: Participate in Mayo Clinic’s upcoming AI Summit
item.description: Mayo Clinic will hold its 2024 Artificial Intelligence (AI) Summit, "Generative Multimodal AI — Potentials and Challenges," on July 8–9 in Rochester and virtually. The event will bring together AI experts and the healthcare community to discuss advances in large multimodal models and their use in healthcare. item.description: A savvy black entrepreneur guides you on an eczema-friendly shopping spree.

item.description: Skin longevity for the win.

item.title: Mayo Clinic Minute: Common types of skin cancer
item.description: Skin cancer is the most common cancer in the U.S., affecting millions worldwide. This cancer comes in two main types: melanoma, which is less common but more deadly, and nonmelanoma skin cancers, which include basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma. Dr. Collin Costello, a Mayo Clinic dermatologist, says these nonmelanoma skin cancers are more prevalent – and with early diagnosis and […] The post Mayo Clinic Minute: Common types of skin cancer appeared first on Mayo Clinic News Network .

item.title: Behind the Spike in Colorectal Cancer Among Young Americans
item.description: Colorectal cancer cases increased a whopping 333% among 15- to 19-year-olds and 185% among 20- to 24-year-olds from 1999 to 2020.

item.description: Probiotics get all the attention, but there's more to well-rounded gut health.

item.title: Mayo Clinic Minute: Tips for protecting babies from harmful UV rays
item.description: Skin cancer is the most common cancer in the U.S., and it only takes one blistering sunburn during childhood or adolescence to nearly double a person's chance of developing melanoma later in life, according to the American Academy of Dermatology Association. Since babies are much more prone to sunburn than older kids, it's especially important […] The post Mayo Clinic Minute: Tips for protecting babies from harmful UV rays appeared first on Mayo Clinic News Network .
